study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bamboo vinegar (BV) solution could improve the phytoremediation efficiency of Perilla frutescens in cadmium (Cd)-contaminated soil and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that BV application increased Cd accumulation in Perilla frutescens leaves, enhanced enzyme activities (superoxide dismutase and catalase), and improved plant tolerance to Cd. It also boosted the Transfer Factor of Cd from roots to stems and overall Cd enrichment in aerial parts by up to 57.70% and 54.03%, respectively.
population_specificity: Perilla frutescens plants under Cd stress (2 mg·L⁻¹).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined effects of microplastics (PVC) and copper (Cu) pollution on the germination and physiological responses of perilla seeds.
results_summary: Low Cu concentrations promoted perilla seed germination, while medium to high concentrations inhibited it and deteriorated seed morphology. Low PVC concentrations mitigated some Cu-induced stress by enhancing antioxidant activity, but high PVC worsened germination metrics.
population_specificity: Perilla seeds in a controlled cultivation environment.
effective_dosage: 8 mg • L-1 Cu, with PVC concentrations varying (e.g., 10 and 5000 units, exact scale not specified).
study_duration: Measurements peaked at 24 hours; total duration unclear.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect and antioxidant activity of Perilla frutescens var. acuta (PFA) on busulfan-induced testicular dysfunction in mice.
results_summary: PFA treatment significantly improved testis weight, sperm quality, testosterone levels, and antioxidant enzyme activity while reducing oxidative stress and histological damage caused by busulfan.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 male mice with busulfan-induced testicular dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the physical and oxidative stability of high internal phase emulsions (HIPEs) using phosphorylated perilla protein isolate (PPI) combined with protocatechuic acid (PA).
results_summary: The study found that phosphorylated PPI-PA conjugates (LPPI-PA) improved emulsion stability by reducing droplet size, increasing interfacial protein adsorption, and inhibiting lipid oxidation, as evidenced by lower levels of lipid hydroperoxide and malondialdehyde.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synthesis, characterization, and potential therapeutic applications of silver nanoparticles (PFRAE-AgNPs) derived from rosmarinic acid extract of Perilla frutescens.
results_summary: The study found that PFRAE-AgNPs exhibited potent antibacterial, antioxidant, and anticancer activities, along with high stability and biocompatibility, suggesting their potential for clinical and therapeutic use.
population_specificity: In vitro testing on bacterial pathogens (Gram-positive and Gram-negative) and human cancer cell lines (COLO205, PC-3, A549, SKOV3) as well as normal (CHO) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active compounds, targets, and mechanisms of Perilla frutescens leaf in treating allergic asthma using network pharmacology and experimental validation.
results_summary: PF leaf improved lung function and reduced lung injury in OVA-induced allergic asthma mice by lowering OVA-specific IgE, IL-4, IL-5, and TNF-α levels. Network pharmacology identified 50 core targets and the MAPK pathway as key mechanisms, confirmed by downregulation of p-ERK, p-JNK, and p-p38 in WB analysis.
population_specificity: OVA-allergic asthma murine model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purple perilla frutescens extract (PPE) and α-asarone could improve dyslipidemia-associated inflammation and inhibit atheroma formation in apoE-deficient mice.
results_summary: PPE and α-asarone improved plasma lipid profiles, reduced systemic inflammation, suppressed aorta atherogenesis, and diminished macrophage accumulation in apoE-deficient mice fed a high-cholesterol diet. They also enhanced hepatic HDL-C trafficking and transcription of related genes.
population_specificity: Apolipoprotein E (apoE)-deficient mice fed a high-cholesterol diet.
effective_dosage: 10-20 mg/kg PPE and α-asarone, orally administered.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-cancer activity of extracellular vesicles derived from perilla leaves (Perex) in breast cancer cells, particularly those with high caveolin-1 levels.
results_summary: Perex demonstrated potent anti-cancer effects, inhibiting proliferation, migration, and invasion of MDA-MB-231 cancer cells while showing selectivity for cells with high caveolin-1 levels, reducing side effects on normal cells. The study highlighted Perex's high productivity, low cost, and therapeutic potential for breast cancer.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of perilla leaf extract (PLE) and its main phenols (caffeic acid and rosmarinic acid) on oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) cells, including viability inhibition, cytokine suppression, and potential adjuvant therapy benefits.
results_summary: PLE and its phenols (CA and RA) inhibited OSCC cell viability dose-dependently, suppressed IL-1β secretion, and enhanced sensitivity to EGFR inhibitors. Chronic treatment with CA/RA mixtures showed stronger inhibitory effects on colony formation than low-dose cisplatin, likely due to apoptosis induction.
population_specificity: Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) cells (OC3 cell line)
effective_dosage: Optimal CA/RA combination ratio was 1:2 at concentrations of 300-500 μM; gefitinib (5 μM); cisplatin (1 μM)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism by which Perilla essential oil treats acute lung injury (ALI) using network pharmacology, molecular docking, and in vitro assays.
results_summary: The study identified 68 key targets of Perilla oil for ALI treatment, linked to inflammatory signaling pathways like NF-κB. In vitro experiments showed Perilla essential oil significantly reduced NO and TNF-α levels and inhibited NF-κB activation, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cells (a murine macrophage cell line) treated with LPS to model ALI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic effects of Perilla frutescens extracts on prostate cancer cells (DU-145) and explore potential interactions of its metabolites with prostate cancer targets.
results_summary: The ethanol extract of P. frutescens leaves showed the highest cytotoxicity against prostate cancer cells, with rosmarinic acid identified as the major metabolite. Network and gene ontology analyses revealed significant effects on molecular functions, biological processes, and pathways related to prostate cancer.
population_specificity: In vitro prostate cancer cells (DU-145) and in silico analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of nano selenium (NSe) and imidacloprid (IMI) on the quality, physiological biochemistry, and secondary metabolites in Perilla frutescens, focusing on mitigating IMI-induced oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that IMI-induced stress disrupted phenylpropanoid biosynthesis, reducing key metabolite levels, while exogenous NSe application restored these metabolites and improved biochemical disorder and leaf quality by optimizing the phenylpropanoid pathway and enhancing antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Perilla frutescens (L.) Britt. plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant activity, phenolic compounds, and inhibitory effects of perilla seed meal extracts against enzymes related to diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The 75% ethanol extract showed the highest phenolic and flavonoid content, along with strong antioxidant activity and significant inhibitory effects against α-glucosidase and α-amylase, suggesting potential for diabetes prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Not specified (extract concentrations used for analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the antidepressant mechanisms of Perilla frutescens essential oil (PFEO) by examining its effects on monoamine neurotransmitters and the BDNF/TrkB signaling pathway.
results_summary: PFEO inhalation significantly improved depressive symptoms in CUMS rats, increasing sugar water preference and reducing immobility time. It elevated monoamine neurotransmitter levels and upregulated BDNF/TrkB signaling in the hippocampus and cerebral cortex.
population_specificity: CUMS (chronic unpredictable mild stress) rat model of depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate the antifungal compounds in Perilla frutescens against Trichophyton mentagrophytes and explore their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Rosmarinic acid from Perilla showed significant antifungal activity by inhibiting enolase expression in the glycolysis pathway, reducing fungal metabolism. Transcriptomic and proteomic analyses confirmed its impact on carbon metabolism and glutathione pathways.
population_specificity: Trichophyton mentagrophytes (fungal pathogen) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biomimetic synthesis of silver nanoparticles using Perilla frutescens flavonoid extract (PFFE) and assess their potential biomedical applications, including anticancer, antibacterial, and antioxidant effects.
results_summary: PFFE-synthesized silver nanoparticles (PFFE-AgNPs) demonstrated cytotoxic effects against cancer cell lines (COLO205 and B16F10), significant antibacterial activity against Gram-positive and Gram-negative pathogens, and antioxidant properties by quenching free radicals. The nanoparticles were stable, monodispersed, and exhibited potential for biomedical applications.
population_specificity: In vitro studies on cancer cell lines (human colon carcinoma COLO205 and mouse melanoma B16F10) and bacterial pathogens (Listeria monocytogens, Enterococcus faecalis, Salmonella typhi, Acinetobacter baumannii).
effective_dosage: IC50 concentrations of 59.57 μg/mL (COLO205) and 69.33 μg/mL (B16F10) for cytotoxicity; 72.81 µg/mL (DPPH) and 92.48 µg/mL (H2O2) for antioxidant activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the chemical composition and molecular mechanisms of Perilla frutescens for cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that Perilla frutescens has active components (perilla aldehyde, rosmarinic acid, lignan, and isoestrogen) with potential cancer therapeutic effects, and perilla seed oil may prevent colorectal cancer due to omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of light and dark treatments on rosmarinic acid production, antioxidant activity, and antibacterial properties in P. frutescens microgreens.
results_summary: Microgreens grown under light and dark conditions showed increased dry weight, rosmarinic acid, and total phenolic content, with peak accumulation at 20 days. Both extracts exhibited strong antioxidant and antibacterial activity, with light-treated microgreens showing higher antimicrobial effects.
population_specificity: P. frutescens microgreens (plant-based study, no human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on growth conditions, not administered dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of Perilla Frutescens Extract (PFE) for relieving pain and improving knee joint function in semi-healthy individuals with mild knee joint pain.
results_summary: PFE significantly reduced VAS and WOMAC scores compared to placebo, indicating improved pain relief and joint function. No significant changes were observed in inflammation-related laboratory parameters, and adverse events were minor and unlikely related to the intervention.
population_specificity: Semi-healthy individuals with mild knee joint pain (VAS score < 50 mm) and no radiological arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether distant hybridization between tobacco and Perilla frutescens could enhance cadmium phytoremediation potential by improving Cd tolerance and accumulation.
results_summary: The hybrid "ZSY" showed superior Cd accumulation in shoots and roots compared to its parent species, along with enhanced physiological responses (e.g., higher SOD and CAT activities) and secondary metabolite production (e.g., alkaloids and phenolic compounds) under Cd stress.
population_specificity: Seedlings of Perilla frutescens, tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum var. 78-04), and their hybrid (N. tabacum var. ZSY) at the six-leaf stage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressant-like efficacy of fermented Perilla frutescens (FPF) and its underlying mechanisms in sleep deprivation-induced stress mice.
results_summary: FPF treatment reduced stress hormone levels, increased serotonin and dopamine levels, reversed proinflammatory cytokine expression, and modulated the BDNF/TrkB/ERK/CREB signaling pathway in stressed mice. Protocatechuic acid and luteolin-7-O-glucuronide were identified as major active components.
population_specificity: Sleep deprivation-induced stress mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an ethanol extract of Perilla frutescens leaves (EPF) could inhibit adrenergic agonist-induced cancer cell metastasis by regulating epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
results_summary: EPF effectively reversed adrenergic agonist-induced migration, invasion, and EMT markers (E-cadherin, N-cadherin, Snail, Slug) in breast and liver cancer cells by suppressing Src phosphorylation. The antimetastatic effect of EPF was diminished when cells were transfected with constitutively activated Src.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells and Hep3B human hepatocellular carcinoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of Perilla frutescens, alone or combined with Lactobacillus plantarum a214 or citric acid, on forage oat silage quality and microbial profiles during ensiling and aerobic exposure.
results_summary: Perilla frutescens, especially when combined with citric acid (CAPF), improved silage aerobic stability by suppressing yeasts, increasing acetic acids, and reducing dry matter loss. It also shifted bacterial and fungal community composition, enhancing silage quality.
population_specificity: Forage oat silage (agricultural application, not human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Perilla frutescens (PFAE) could alleviate TMAO-induced kidney injury by regulating ASK1-JNK phosphorylation in both in vitro and in vivo models.
results_summary: PFAE (5 mg/mL) inhibited TMAO-induced apoptosis by downregulating ASK1-JNK phosphorylation in vitro and reduced TMAO-induced renal damage in vivo by the same mechanism. The study confirmed that P. frutescens may be effective in mitigating TMAO-related kidney injury in CKD.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) models (in vitro and in vivo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify bioactive compounds in Perilla frutescens targeting β2-AR and evaluate their antiasthmatic effects and mechanisms in a murine model of allergic asthma.
results_summary: Rosmarinic acid (RA) from Perilla significantly reduced lung inflammation, Th2 cytokine production, and IgE secretion by inhibiting the NF-κB pathway, demonstrating effectiveness in counteracting allergic airway inflammation.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice) with allergic asthma induced by ovalbumin and aluminum hydroxide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize anti-inflammatory compounds (cyclolignan enantiomers) from Perilla frutescens leaves and evaluate their effects on pro-inflammatory factors and mediators.
results_summary: The study isolated two pairs of cyclolignan enantiomers from Perilla leaves, which demonstrated notable anti-inflammatory effects by reducing pro-inflammatory factors (NO, TNF-α, IL-6) and mediators (iNOS, COX-2). These findings suggest cyclolignans are key active components contributing to Perilla's anti-inflammatory properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal study implied, but not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ultrasonic-assisted pH shift treatment on the structural and functional properties of perilla protein isolate (PPI), particularly its emulsifying and foaming capabilities.
results_summary: Ultrasonic-assisted pH shift treatment significantly improved the solubility, foamability, and emulsifying stability of PPI by breaking down large aggregates into smaller particles and altering protein structure to increase surface hydrophobicity. This led to faster adsorption rates, tighter interfacial structures, and higher elastic modulus at air- and oil-water interfaces.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on perilla protein isolate)
effective_dosage: Ultrasonic treatment (20 KHz, 400 W, 20 min) combined with pH shift (pH 10 and 12)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Perilla fruit water extract (PFWE) could reduce lung inflammation and neutrophil infiltration in a LPS-stimulated murine model and explore its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: PFWE decreased airway resistance, neutrophil infiltration, vessel permeability, and pro-inflammatory cytokine levels in vivo, and inhibited inflammatory markers and the MAPK/JNK-AP-1/c-Fos pathway in vitro. The findings suggest PFWE may assist in treating ARDS.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice and A549 human lung epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the molecular mechanisms by which light intensity affects anthocyanin accumulation in perilla leaves.
results_summary: The study found that elevated light intensity increased the accumulation of 60 flavonoid metabolites and upregulated 983 genes, identifying key genes (CHI, DFR, ANS) and transcription factors (MYB, bHLH, bZIP, ERF, NAC) involved in anthocyanin biosynthesis. Light treatment significantly influenced gene expression related to anthocyanin production, particularly malonylshisonin biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Light-sensitive perilla variety (plant study, not human).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Perilla frutescens leaf extract (PFL) could exert therapeutic efficacy against vascular dementia (VaD) by attenuating neuroinflammation.
results_summary: PFL treatment significantly attenuated VaD-associated memory deficits, hippocampal neuronal death, and microglial activation in rats. It also reversed LPS-induced upregulations of inflammatory markers and related signaling pathways in microglial cells.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats with induced vascular dementia (VaD).
effective_dosage: Low (30 mg/kg), medium (60 mg/kg), and high (90 mg/kg) doses administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the phytochemistry and pharmacological activities of Perilla frutescens, identifying its bioactive compounds and their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that Perilla frutescens contains approximately 400 bioactive compounds with diverse pharmacological effects, including anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antimicrobial, and neuroprotective properties, and potential applications in treating diabetes, cardiovascular disorders, and neurodegenerative diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the appropriate dose of n-3 fatty acids from perilla oil to improve gut function, microbiota, and energy provision in trained athletes.
results_summary: Higher perilla oil intake (9 g/d) significantly reduced spoilage bacteria (Proteobacteria) and increased butyrate-producing bacteria (Lachnospiraceae), improved gut function, and lowered urinary indoxyl sulphate. Lower intake (3 g/d) also showed benefits but to a lesser extent.
population_specificity: Thirty-six female athletes training six times per week.
effective_dosage: 9 g/d (high oil intake), 3 g/d (low oil intake), and placebo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of Perilla frutescens extract (PLE) on COPD airway inflammation and elucidate its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PLE significantly reduced inflammatory cell infiltration, leukocyte levels, and inflammatory mediators in COPD mice, and inhibited inflammatory factors and ROS in LPS-stimulated cells. The mechanism involved suppression of the TLR4/Syk/PKC/NF-κB p65 signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Cigarette smoke/lipopolysaccharide-induced COPD mice and LPS-stimulated RAW264.7 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the alleviating effect of essential oil from Perilla frutescens on psoriasis-like lesions in mice and its potential anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that Perilla essential oil (PO) reduced psoriasis-like lesions, decreased neutrophil activation markers, and inhibited inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, IL-17, IL-23, and NF-κB, with concentration-dependent effects.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with imiquimod-induced psoriasis-like lesions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (low concentrations showed the best results).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify a shorter and more efficient pretreatment strategy (compared to cold stratification) to induce germination of perilla mericarps.
results_summary: Sulfuric acid treatment reduced germination rates, while gibberellin treatment achieved equivalent or similar germination rates as cold stratification, particularly in older mericarps with low germination energy. A short gibberellin treatment was suggested as a convenient and safe alternative to cold stratification.
population_specificity: Pure strains of perilla mericarps.
effective_dosage: Gibberellin at 100 ppm (8 h and 1 h) and 10 ppm (5 min); sulfuric acid for 10 min and 1 min.
study_duration: Varied by treatment (5 min to 8 h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different microwave power and treatment times on the bioactive components and oxidative stability of perilla oil.
results_summary: Microwave treatment at 700 W for 10 min significantly increased oxidative stability, total phytosterols, Maillard reaction products, and DPPH radical scavenging activity in perilla oil, but reduced total tocopherol content, phenolic compounds, and lipase activity. Fatty acids were slightly affected by microwave treatment.
population_specificity: Perilla seeds (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Microwave treatment at 380 W, 540 W, or 700 W for 0-10 min.
study_duration: Up to 10 min of microwave treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pro-angiogenic effects of essential oil from Perilla frutescens (EOPF) and its main component perillaldehyde in treating ischemic cardio-cerebrovascular diseases.
results_summary: EOPF and perillaldehyde significantly promoted angiogenesis by repairing sunitinib-injured intersegmental vessels in zebrafish embryos and enhancing proliferation, migration, and tube formation in human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs). The effects were mediated by increased p-ERK1/2 to ERK1/2 and Bcl-2 to Bax expression ratios.
population_specificity: Transgenic Tg (flk1:EGFP) zebrafish embryos and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active components of Perilla frutescens and their mechanisms in treating chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 3-5.
results_summary: The study identified 19 active components in Perilla, with luteolin emerging as a critical component that reduces renal tubular apoptosis by inhibiting oxidative stress and downregulating MAPK and p53 pathways. Molecular docking and in vitro experiments confirmed luteolin's efficacy in alleviating adriamycin-induced renal damage.
population_specificity: Focused on chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 3-5, specifically renal tubular epithelial cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of perilla seed oil (PSO) and rosmarinic acid-rich fraction (RA-RF) in a TNF-α-induced A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell model.
results_summary: PSO and RA-RF significantly reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation and decreased mRNA expression of inflammatory markers (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α, COX-2) and protein levels of MnSOD, FOXO1, NF-κB, and phosphorylated JNK in A549 cells.
population_specificity: A549 human lung adenocarcinoma cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of perilla oil (PO) on ulcerative colitis symptoms in a DSS-induced mouse model.
results_summary: PO significantly reversed colon shortening and disease activity scores, reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β), and improved tight junction protein expression compared to controls. It also mitigated body weight loss more effectively than fish oil.
population_specificity: Five-week-old male C57BL/6J mice with DSS-induced ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different doses of Perilla seed oil (PSO) and metformin on gut microbiota, inflammation, and metabolic parameters in high-fat diet-induced obese rats.
results_summary: PSO improved gut barrier integrity, reduced gut inflammation, oxidative stress, metabolic endotoxemia, and insulin resistance in high-fat diet-fed rats, though metformin showed greater benefits.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how ultrasonic treatment affects the structural and functional properties of perilla protein isolate (PPI) and its ability to stabilize emulsions.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment reduced PPI particle size, altered its structure, and improved solubility, water/oil holding capacity, foaming, and emulsifying properties. Emulsions stabilized by ultrasonic-treated PPI showed higher stability due to smaller droplet size and increased interfacial protein adsorption.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and optimize a method for detecting chlorpyrifos, diazinon, and their by-products in perilla leaves and cherry tomatoes using liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry.
results_summary: The optimized method improved recoveries of most compounds to 80% or higher, except for diethyl phosphate and 3,5,6-trichloro-2-pyridinol. The method showed good linearity, recovery values (82.1–113.3%), and reproducibility (intraday ≤8.6%, interday ≤9.9%). It was applied to assess degradation efficiency of pesticides during plasma treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on perilla leaves and cherry tomatoes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to preliminarily evaluate the efficacy and effect size of perilla oil, combined with Bifidobacterium, on fear of cancer recurrence (FCR) in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as planned and registered but not yet completed.
population_specificity: Outpatients with invasive breast cancer aged 20+ years, who completed chemotherapy at least 6 months prior (hormone therapy ongoing allowed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ethanol, activated carbon, and activated kaolin treatments on the volatile organic compounds (VOCs), physicochemical characteristics, and fatty acid composition of Perilla seed oil (PSO).
results_summary: The study found that ethanol treatment was more effective than activated carbon or activated kaolin in removing VOCs from PSO, while fatty acid composition remained largely unchanged. The treatments primarily affected the peroxide value and color of the oil, with ethanol showing the greatest impact.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory analysis of PSO samples).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment methods described but no dosage details provided).
study_duration: Not specified (laboratory study without stated intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dynamic high-pressure microfluidization (DHPM) could improve the functional properties of perilla protein isolate (PPI).
results_summary: DHPM treatment reduced particle size and absolute potential of PPI, increased surface hydrophobicity and free sulfhydryl content, and enhanced thermal stability at 90 MPa and 120 MPa. Functional properties like solubility, foaming, and emulsifying capacities improved most effectively at 120 MPa.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on perilla protein isolate)
effective_dosage: DHPM treatment at different pressures (90 MPa and 120 MPa)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of UV-B radiation intensity, duration, and irradiation method on growth, flowering, and phytochemical concentration in greenhouse-grown perilla.
results_summary: Continuous UV-B irradiation at 0.05 W m-2 for 3 h increased rosmarinic acid (RA) concentration two-fold without reducing phenotypic quality or productivity, while higher intensities or durations caused leaf color changes and reduced fresh weight. Intermittent illumination for 6 h inhibited flowering without affecting phytochemical concentration.
population_specificity: Greenhouse-grown perilla plants.
effective_dosage: UV-B radiation at 0.05-0.2 W m-2, applied continuously or intermittently for 3 or 6 h.
study_duration: Single exposure sessions of 3 or 6 h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary perilla seed oil (PO) intake on cognitive functions and mental health in healthy elderly Japanese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that PO intake significantly increased serum biological antioxidant potential and α-linolenic acid levels in red blood cell plasma membranes, with improvements in cognitive function and apathy scores after 12 months.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly Japanese individuals aged 64-84 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents from traditional Chinese medicine, specifically evaluating Perilla leaf extract (PLE) for its antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2.
results_summary: PLE demonstrated significant antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2, inhibiting viral replication by inactivating the virion and showing additive-to-synergistic effects when combined with remdesivir. It also reduced viral RNA/protein synthesis and cytokine release in human lung epithelial cells.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using Vero E6 cells and human lung epithelial cell line Calu-3.
effective_dosage: EC50 of 0.12 ± 0.06 mg/mL in Vero E6 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and quantify polyphenolic compounds, particularly rosmarinic acid and scutellarin, in Perilla frutescens leaves and assess how their content varies with plant position, growth stage, and harvesting time.
results_summary: The study found that scutellarin, a flavone glucuronide, was the second most abundant polyphenol in Perilla leaves after rosmarinic acid. Rosmarinic acid and scutellarin content varied based on plant position and growth stage, while harvesting time only affected rosmarinic acid levels.
population_specificity: Perilla frutescens (L.) Britton var. frutescens (egoma) leaves.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoegomaketone (IK) from Perilla frutescens var. crispa promotes wound healing in human keratinocytes.
results_summary: IK significantly enhanced keratinocyte proliferation and migration in a dose-dependent manner, activating the MAPK/ERK pathway and cell cycle progression, suggesting therapeutic potential for wound healing.
population_specificity: Human keratinocyte cell line HaCaT

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiallergic asthma effects of Perilla leaf extract (PLE) and explore its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: PLE significantly reduced airway inflammation in OVA-induced asthma mice and suppressed inflammatory responses in RBL-2H3 cells and human PBMCs by inhibiting the Syk pathway and its downstream signals (NF-κB, PKC, and cPLA2).
population_specificity: OVA-induced asthma mice, RBL-2H3 cells, and human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor effects of Perilla frutescens var. acuta leaf extracts (PLE) on Hippo-YAP/TAZ signaling in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.
results_summary: PLE inhibited YAP/TAZ activity by inducing their phosphorylation and disrupting the YAP/TAZ-TEAD complex, leading to reduced cell viability, increased apoptosis, and inhibited migration in TNBC cell lines. These effects were dependent on LATS1/2, a key component of the Hippo pathway.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cell lines (MDA-MB-231 and BT549).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of perilla oil on high-fat diet-induced colonic inflammation in mice.
results_summary: Perilla oil significantly reduced colon inflammation, improved gut microbiota balance, lowered proinflammatory cytokines, and enhanced intestinal barrier function, with effects comparable to fish oil.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice (5 weeks old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify active ingredients in Perilla leaves extract (PLE) targeting Syk and evaluate their effects on allergic asthma inflammation.
results_summary: Three active ingredients (roseoside, vicenin-2, and rosmarinic acid) were identified from PLE, showing significant Syk inhibition and anti-inflammatory effects in allergic asthma models, with a synergistic effect observed when combined.
population_specificity: OVA-induced allergic asthma mouse model, human PBMCs, and RBL-2H3 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and anti-ulcer activities of Perilla frutescens fruit oil (PFO) and PFO-supplemented soybean milk (PFO-SM) in animal models.
results_summary: PFO demonstrated potent analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and anti-ulcer properties, while PFO-SM showed only analgesic effects. PFO significantly inhibited gastric ulcers and ear edema but did not affect carrageenan-induced hind paw edema.
population_specificity: Mice and rats (animal models).
effective_dosage: PFO (2.5 and 5 mL/kg; 0.1 and 1 mL/ear topically), PFO-SM (0.05 mL PFO equivalence/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how in vitro gastrointestinal digestion affects the active compounds and biological activities of Perilla frutescens leaf extract (PFLE).
results_summary: The study found significant losses in phenolic and flavonoid content (53% and 40%, respectively) and reduced antioxidant activity after digestion. Despite these losses, PFLE retained some antioxidant, α-glucosidase inhibitory, acetylcholinesterase inhibitory, and MCF-7 cell proliferation inhibitory abilities.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the functional properties and biological activities of hydrolysates derived from perilla seed meal (PSM) using different proteases.
results_summary: The study found that PSM protein hydrolysates exhibited high solubility, water/oil absorption capacity, antioxidant activity (scavenging radicals), angiotensin I-converting enzyme inhibition, and anti-inflammatory effects, with efficacy varying by protease type. Trypsin-treated hydrolysate showed the highest scavenging activity (IC50 of 109.72 µg/mL).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of replacing soybean meal with perilla seed meal (PSM) on growth performance, meat quality, and fatty acid composition in broilers.
results_summary: Broilers fed diets with 1% and 2% PSM showed higher body weights, improved weight gain, and better feed conversion ratios. PSM at 2% increased fat composition in breast meat, water holding capacity, and linolenic acid levels in thigh meat.
population_specificity: One-day-old ROSS 308 broiler chicks (initial weight 44.8 ± 0.4 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and molecular mechanism of α-linolenic acid-enriched cold-pressed perilla oil (LEP) on hepatic steatosis in a high-fat diet-induced obesity model.
results_summary: LEP treatment significantly reduced liver weight, lipid droplet accumulation, and expression of adipogenesis/lipogenesis factors while increasing lipolysis. It also suppressed ER stress-mediated autophagy and modulated key signaling pathways, indicating anti-hepatic steatosis effects.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese C57BL/6N mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Thai perilla nutlet extracts on endothelial activation and endothelial microparticles (EMPs) generation in TNF-α-induced EA.hy926 cells.
results_summary: The study found that Thai perilla nutlet extracts, particularly the ethanol extract, significantly reduced TNF-α-induced endothelial activation and EMPs generation by decreasing ICAM-1 expression and IL-6 overproduction in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: TNF-α-induced EA.hy926 endothelial cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Perilla frutescens leaf powder (PLP) reduces Ox-LDL levels, improves home blood pressure, and enhances biological antioxidant potential in healthy individuals.
results_summary: PLP significantly decreased plasma Ox-LDL levels, increased biological antioxidant potential and alpha-linolenic acid levels, and reduced systolic blood pressure in prehypertensive subjects compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy Japanese volunteers aged 30-60 years (n = 60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a nutraceutical containing Perilla frutescens and ginger extract for treating functional dyspepsia (FD).
results_summary: The study found significant symptom reduction (epigastric pain, heartburn, reflux, nausea, etc.) starting in the first week, with further improvement after two weeks. The treatment was well tolerated, with mild, transient side effects.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with functional dyspepsia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Perilla oil (PO) intake improves mental health conditions in healthy adult Japanese volunteers.
results_summary: PO administration significantly improved depression and apathy scores, decreased serum norepinephrine and serotonin levels, and increased α-linolenic acid (LNA) levels in erythrocyte plasma membranes.
population_specificity: Healthy adult Japanese volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Perilla frutescens leaves attenuate acute colitis in mice and inhibit angiogenic processes in human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC).
results_summary: Dietary Perilla supplementation reduced colitis severity in mice by lowering inflammatory and angiogenic mediators. The ethanol extract of Perilla also inhibited LPS-stimulated angiogenic processes in HUVEC.
population_specificity: DSS-treated mice and LPS-stimulated human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of unsaponifiable matter (USM) from perilla seed meal on UVB-induced skin aging in Hs68 cells.
results_summary: USM blocked UVB-induced cytotoxicity, reduced reactive oxygen species production, attenuated matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) expression, and restored collagen synthesis by modulating the TGF-β/Smad pathway and AP-1 activity. These findings suggest USM may be an effective anti-photoaging ingredient.
population_specificity: Hs68 cells (human dermal fibroblasts)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of Perilla Frutescens var. Acuta Kudo (PF) with other herbal extracts could enhance endometrial receptivity by increasing leukemia inhibitory factor (LIF) expression and adhesion molecule activity.
results_summary: The PRP (PL, RG, PF) combination increased LIF expression in Ishikawa cells and improved adhesion between Ishikawa and JAr cells. Knock-down of LIF expression reduced PRP-induced adhesion and adhesion molecule expression, suggesting LIF mediates these effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Ishikawa (endometrial) and JAr (trophoblast) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-arthritic effects of a radiation mutant Perilla frutescens leaf extract (SFE-M) and wild type extract (SFE-W) in a mouse model of collagen antibody-induced arthritis.
results_summary: SFE-M significantly reduced arthritis severity, paw volume, and inflammation compared to untreated CAIA mice, while SFE-W showed no significant effects. SFE-M also lowered the neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio by 37%.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice with collagen antibody-induced arthritis (CAIA).
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg/day for both SFE-M and SFE-W.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Perilla oil (PerO) could regulate intestinal microbiota and alleviate insulin resistance through the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway in type-2 diabetic KKAy mice.
results_summary: PerO intervention reduced fasting blood glucose, lipid droplet accumulation, and body weight loss while increasing insulin levels. It also improved liver enzyme levels, activated the PI3K/AKT pathway, and restored gut microbiota diversity.
population_specificity: Type-2 diabetic KKAy mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of replacing fat with Perilla seeds in meatballs on nutritional composition, texture, and sensory properties.
results_summary: The addition of Perilla seeds improved texture, increased polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), dietary fiber, and protein content, and enhanced flavor and satiety, with 10% (w/w) being the most effective dosage.
population_specificity: Meatball preparation (in vitro study, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 2',3'-dihydroxy-4',6'-dimethoxychalcone (DDC) from green perilla leaves could protect HaCaT cells from UV-A-induced ROS production and cell damage.
results_summary: DDC significantly suppressed UV-A-induced ROS production and showed cytoprotective effects when administered before and after UV-A irradiation. It increased heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) expression, which contributed to its protective effects.
population_specificity: HaCaT cells (human keratinocyte cell line)
study_duration: 24 hours before and after UV-A irradiation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oligo-gellan and salt stress on the yield and quality of red perilla leaves, focusing on growth, nutrient content, and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: Oligo-gellan enhanced plant growth, nutrient accumulation, and antioxidant activity under non-saline conditions and mitigated salt stress effects by reducing biomass loss and sodium accumulation while improving photosynthetic pigments and antioxidant activity. Extracts from treated plants effectively inhibited bacterial growth.
population_specificity: Red perilla (Perilla frutescens var. crispa f. purpurea) plants.
effective_dosage: 100 mM NaCl for salt stress; oligo-gellan concentration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DDC, a component of green perilla, could prevent Aβ-induced neuronal death and aggregation, and whether its neuroprotective effects were mediated through the Nrf2-ARE pathway.
results_summary: DDC suppressed Aβ aggregation and provided neuroprotective effects against Aβ-induced cytotoxicity, likely through activation of the Nrf2-ARE pathway, though this mechanism was less involved in its neuroprotective action. However, DDC did not affect Aβ-induced neuronal death under the tested conditions.
population_specificity: Cortical neurons (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability, bioavailability, anti-inflammatory, and antibacterial effects of perilla oil nanoemulsion (PON) compared to linseed oil nanoemulsion (LON).
results_summary: PON and LON demonstrated good stability under various conditions (pH, temperature, NaCl concentration) and showed anti-inflammatory and antibacterial effects. No pathological differences were observed in mice organs, and PON/LON enhanced intestinal absorption.
population_specificity: Kunming mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ACTPER, a botanical extract containing Perilla frutescens, could effectively alleviate itch and improve skin barrier function in a dry skin model.
results_summary: ACTPER significantly alleviated dry skin-related itching and improved skin barrier function by upregulating filaggrin expression via the AhR signaling pathway in both mice and human keratinocytes. The effects were dose-dependent, and molecular docking suggested direct binding of ACTPER compounds to AhR.
population_specificity: Acetone-induced dry skin mice model and human keratinocyte-derived HaCaT cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and characterize carbon quantum dots (CQDs) from purple perilla for use as a fluorescent probe to detect silver ions (Ag+) and assess their biocompatibility for potential bioimaging applications.
results_summary: The study successfully synthesized water-soluble, fluorescent CQDs from perilla, demonstrating high selectivity and sensitivity for Ag+ detection with a low detection limit (1.4 nM). The CQDs also exhibited low cytotoxicity and good biocompatibility, suggesting potential for bioimaging in living cells.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perilla seed oil, as an additional treatment, provides neuroprotective effects and improves cognitive function in patients with mild to moderate dementia.
results_summary: Perilla seed oil did not significantly improve cognitive function compared to placebo but significantly reduced total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol. No adverse effects on kidney, liver, blood components, or glucose metabolism were observed.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of perilla oil on obesity-induced hepatic and vascular changes in high-fat diet-fed mice and explore its potential therapeutic mechanisms.
results_summary: Perilla oil reduced serum cholesterol, arterial and hepatic lipid accumulation, and improved lipid metabolism by increasing lipolytic proteins and decreasing lipogenic proteins in the liver compared to palm oil.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and identify new compounds from Perilla frutescens leaves and evaluate their inhibitory effects on xanthine oxidase in vitro.
results_summary: The study isolated three new compounds from Perilla frutescens, with one (compound 2) showing more potent xanthine oxidase inhibitory activity than the clinical drug allopurinol, acting as a mixed-type inhibitor.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Perilla frutescens sprout extract (PFSE) on glomerular mesangial cell proliferation and extracellular matrix accumulation under high glucose conditions, as well as its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: PFSE attenuated high glucose-induced cell proliferation, hypertrophy, and ECM protein overexpression in murine glomerular mesangial cells. It also inhibited ROS overproduction and NOX2/4 expression while activating AMPK, suggesting a potential role in preventing diabetic nephropathy.
population_specificity: Murine glomerular mesangial cells (MMCs) cultured under high glucose conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the residual characteristics and persistence of fungicides (fluxapyroxad and penthiopyrad) on greenhouse-cultivated perilla leaves and assess their health risks.
results_summary: The study found that fungicide residues in perilla leaves dissipated over time, with 50.0% and 44.2% remaining after 7 days for fluxapyroxad and penthiopyrad, respectively. The health risk was deemed low, with %ADI < 7.3%, suggesting safety for consumption.
population_specificity: Greenhouse-cultivated perilla (Perilla frutescens var. japonica Hara).
effective_dosage: Fluxapyroxad (15.3% suspension concentrate) diluted 2,000-fold; penthiopyrad (20% emulsifiable concentrate) diluted 4,000-fold, sprayed 3 times at 7-day intervals.
study_duration: Samples collected up to 7 days after the final spray.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxicity profile of Perilla seed oil (PSO) in rodents and Beagle dogs to assess its safety for consumption.
results_summary: PSO was well tolerated by rodents at high doses (up to 50 g/kg in mice and 20 g/kg in rats). In dogs, sub-chronic administration (3–12 g/kg/d for 90 days) caused reversible side effects at higher doses, with a NOAEL of 3 g/kg/d.
population_specificity: KM mice, Wistar rats, and Beagle dogs.
effective_dosage: 3, 6, and 12 g/kg/d for dogs; up to 50 g/kg in mice and 20 g/kg in rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiobesity effects of purple perilla (PE) in 3T3-L1 preadipocytes and C57BL/6J mice fed high-fat diets.
results_summary: PE reduced lipid accumulation in adipocytes by modulating adipogenic and lipolytic gene expression. In mice, PE prevented weight gain, improved serum and hepatic lipids, and reduced epididymal fat while upregulating genes related to lipolysis and fatty acid β-oxidation.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 preadipocytes and C57BL/6J mice fed high-fat diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and safety of perilla seed oil as an additional antioxidative therapy in patients with mild to moderate dementia.
results_summary: Perilla seed oil was found to be safe with minimal side effects (nausea and vomiting in 3% of patients) and no significant differences in laboratory results compared to placebo. The study did not report significant efficacy outcomes but noted feasibility and safety.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate dementia (Thai Mini-Mental State Examination score of 10-23 or Thai Montreal Cognitive Assessment score of 12-25).
effective_dosage: Two capsules of 500 milligrams each, four times daily (total 4000 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Perilla seed protein (PSP) as an emulsifier in oil-in-water emulsions under varying conditions (pH, NaCl concentration, thermal treatment).
results_summary: PSP at 1.0 wt% stabilized emulsions effectively, except near its isoelectric point (pH 3.0–5.0). High NaCl concentrations (250–350 mmol/L) and extreme heat (90°C) reduced emulsion stability, while moderate heat (70°C) maintained stability.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of polysaccharide extracts from Perilla frutescens (PEPF) against H2O2-induced oxidative stress in HT22 hippocampus cells.
results_summary: PEPF treatment demonstrated significant neuroprotective effects by reducing oxidative stress, inhibiting apoptosis-related pathways, and enhancing antioxidant activity in H2O2-treated HT22 cells. It also preserved mitochondrial membrane potential and reduced apoptotic markers.
population_specificity: HT22 hippocampus cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the antidepressant-like effects of Perilla aldehyde (PAH) and its underlying mechanism in a rat model of depression induced by chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS).
results_summary: PAH (20, 40 mg/kg) and fluoxetine (FLU, 10 mg/kg) significantly improved depressive-like behaviors, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, and modulated the TXNIP/TRX/NLRP3 pathway in the hippocampus of CUMS-induced rats.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to CUMS to model depression.
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg and 40 mg/kg PAH, 10 mg/kg FLU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Lertal®, a supplement containing Perilla frutescens, in relieving symptoms of seasonal allergic rhinitis and reducing the use of anti-allergic drugs.
results_summary: The study found a highly significant reduction (approximately 70%) in overall symptoms and a 73% reduction in anti-allergic drug use. No noteworthy side effects were reported.
population_specificity: 23 subjects with at least one year history of allergic rhinitis and positive skin prick test or RAST to Parietaria officinalis pollen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chronic administration of P. minor extract on learning, memory, and metabolic pathways in a rat model of chronic cerebral hypoperfusion (CCH).
results_summary: P. minor extract (200 and 300 mg/kg) enhanced recognition and spatial memory in CCH rats, increased hippocampal ACh and GABA expression, and influenced metabolic pathways related to cognitive enhancement.
population_specificity: Rats with induced chronic cerebral hypoperfusion (PBOCCA model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antihypertensive effects of Persicaria minor aqueous extract (AEPM) by assessing its modulation of the ACE/AT1R pathway in PMA-induced HUVECs.
results_summary: AEPM significantly reduced ACE mRNA expression, ACE protein levels, ACE activity, angiotensin II levels, and AT1R expression in PMA-induced HUVECs, with effects comparable to captopril. Ex vivo experiments confirmed AEPM reduced contraction responses in rat aortic rings.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and rat aortic rings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 6-month Persicaria minor (Biokesum®) supplementation on cognition, mood, biomarkers, and brain activation in older adults with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in visual memory, negative mood, BDNF levels, and triglycerides in the Biokesum® group, along with preliminary evidence of enhanced right DLPFC brain activation. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Malaysian community-dwelling older adults (60-75 years old) with MCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in regulating terpenoid biosynthesis in Persicaria minor after inoculation with Fusarium oxysporum.
results_summary: The study found that terpenoid accumulation peaked at 6 days post-inoculation, with α-cedrene, valencene, and β-bisabolene being prominent. Six miRNAs were identified as post-transcriptionally regulating terpenoid biosynthesis, with some showing dynamic expression patterns.
population_specificity: Persicaria minor plants inoculated with Fusarium oxysporum.
study_duration: 9 days (with key measurements at 0, 3, 6, and 9 days post-inoculation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to profile the proteome of Persicaria minor leaves and elucidate protein changes induced by methyl jasmonate (MeJA) elicitation.
results_summary: The study used SWATH-MS technology and transcriptomics to profile the proteome of Persicaria minor, identifying protein changes in response to MeJA treatment. The data was deposited in the ProteomeXchange Consortium (PXD005749).
population_specificity: Persicaria minor (tropical herb) leaves.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how methyl jasmonate (MeJA) treatment influences the proteome of Persicaria minor and identify differentially expressed proteins involved in stress response and metabolic pathways.
results_summary: MeJA treatment induced significant upregulation of proteins related to stress response, lipid metabolism, and secondary metabolite production, while downregulating proteins involved in energy-intensive processes like photosynthesis. A moderate positive correlation was observed between upregulated proteins and their transcripts, suggesting post-transcriptional regulation during stress.
population_specificity: Persicaria minor plants (non-model herbal species)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of miRNAs in regulating phytohormone signaling pathways (MJ and ABA) and their potential correlation with secondary metabolite production in Persicaria minor.
results_summary: The study generated a smallRNA library of Persicaria minor in response to MJ and ABA treatments using next-generation sequencing, with raw reads deposited in the SRA database. This suggests a potential regulatory role of miRNAs in phytohormone-induced secondary metabolite production.
population_specificity: Persicaria minor (Kesum) plants treated with MJ and ABA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether dog ownership and physical activity (both related and unrelated to pet care) influence mental health outcomes via loneliness, and whether these relationships differ between older and younger adult pet owners.
results_summary: Dog owners engaged in higher levels of physical activity (both pet-related and independent), but only non-pet-related physical activity was linked to better mental health. Loneliness levels were similar across age groups, but younger adults experienced stronger associations between loneliness and depression/anxiety compared to older adults.
population_specificity: Australian pet owners (N=588, 76.3% female, aged 18-84).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate risk factors for comorbid symptomatic dry eye (DE) among individuals with hay fever (HF), including pet ownership.
results_summary: Pet ownership was identified as one of the risk factors for comorbid symptomatic DE among individuals with HF, though the study did not quantify the magnitude of this association. The abstract does not provide specific details on how pet ownership influenced DE symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals in Japan who downloaded the AllerSearch smartphone app, including those with hay fever (HF), non-HF, and unknown HF status.
study_duration: Data collected between February 2018 and May 2020 (cross-sectional study, no intervention duration specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Animal-Assisted Therapy (AAT) in promoting healthy ageing by examining its physiological, psychological, and social benefits in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that AAT improves cardiovascular health, mobility, mood, cognition, and reduces anxiety, loneliness, and depression in older adults, likely through mechanisms like oxytocin and dopamine release. Challenges and limitations of AAT in ageing populations were also discussed.
population_specificity: Older adults (geriatric population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on pet ownership as a potential risk factor for cancer, zoonotic diseases in immunocompromised patients, and the role of animal-assisted therapy in cancer patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings but indicates a literature review was conducted to assess claims about pet ownership's risks and benefits for cancer patients.
population_specificity: Cancer patients, particularly those undergoing chemotherapy or immunocompromised.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a minimal-contact mHealth intervention (SMS messages and dog pedometer) in increasing dog-facilitated physical activity (dog walking and play) among young children and evaluating its impact on their overall physical activity and socio-emotional development.
results_summary: The study proposes to evaluate whether SMS prompts to parents and the use of a dog pedometer can increase children's dog walking and play, potentially improving their physical activity levels and socio-emotional well-being. Results are not yet provided as the study appears to be in progress or recently completed.
population_specificity: Parents and children (aged 5-8 years) from dog-owning families in Perth, Western Australia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involves SMS messages over 4 weeks and optional dog pedometer use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of companion animals on the physical and mental health of older adults aged 60+.
results_summary: In 52 of the 70 studies reviewed, companion animals positively impacted mental health (e.g., reducing depression, anxiety, cognitive impairment) and physical health (e.g., increased activity, improved blood pressure and heart rate variability). The findings suggest potential benefits, though more controlled research is needed.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60+

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate factors associated with increased risk of black-legged tick bites and tick-borne diseases, including pet ownership.
results_summary: The study found that pet ownership increased the risk of tick bites, contradicting some widely disseminated recommendations. The mechanisms underlying this relationship require further research.
population_specificity: General population, with specific risk peaks in children aged ≤5 years and adults aged 50-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the autonomic cardiovascular effects of emotional stress in animals and explore the potential risk of cardiovascular diseases in pets living in urban environments.
results_summary: The study suggests pet ownership may help attenuate stress effects in humans, reducing cardiovascular disease risk, but highlights a lack of attention to cardiovascular risks in pets exposed to urban stressors.
population_specificity: Animals (pets) and humans in urban environments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of canine-assisted therapy (CAT) in surgical patients, focusing on blood pressure control, pain management, and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: CAT demonstrated significant reductions in blood pressure and blood pressure variability, improved self-reported pain, and enhanced patient satisfaction in surgical settings. The study highlights CAT as a cost-effective, safe, and noninvasive approach to managing these outcomes.
population_specificity: Surgical patients (adult and pediatric)
study_duration: Not specified (single or multiple sessions implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the extent, nature, and quality of evidence regarding the role and utility of pet ownership for people managing long-term mental health conditions.
results_summary: The review found mixed quantitative evidence on pet ownership benefits (positive, negative, and neutral impacts), while qualitative studies highlighted deep connectivity and multifaceted support pets provide, alongside negative aspects like emotional burden and grief from pet loss.
population_specificity: People living with diagnosable mental health conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review factors influencing the composition of the hand microbiome, including pet ownership.
results_summary: The study found that pet ownership is one of the extrinsic variables impacting the hand microbiome composition, but it did not specify the nature or magnitude of this effect.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (hand microbiome studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of IgE-mediated sensitization to horse allergens in atopic subjects without occupational exposure and its clinical characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that 5.38% of atopic subjects were sensitized to horse dander, with some cases linked to direct or indirect horse contact, while others had no apparent exposure. Horse sensitization was associated with mild to moderate/severe rhinitis and asthma in some patients.
population_specificity: Atopic subjects in Italy with positive skin prick tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether pet ownership during pregnancy and childhood was associated with asthma and atopy at age 7 in a UK population-based birth cohort.
results_summary: Continuous pet ownership was associated with 52% lower odds of atopic asthma but increased risk of non-atopic asthma, particularly for rabbits and rodents. Pet ownership also reduced sensitization to grass, house dust mite, and cat allergens, though rodent ownership increased sensitization to rodent allergen.
population_specificity: UK children from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC) birth cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the epidemiology of human exposure to pet allergens (Fel d 1 and Can f 1), sensitization mechanisms, and environmental intervention strategies to reduce allergen exposure.
results_summary: The study highlights the increasing prevalence of pet dander allergies due to lifestyle changes, debunks misconceptions about hypoallergenic pet breeds, and explores factors influencing allergen shedding and dispersal. It also discusses environmental and pet-directed interventions to mitigate allergen exposure.
population_specificity: General human population, with a focus on socio-economically disadvantaged groups and children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pet therapy improves sleep and life quality in elderly individuals living in a nursing home.
results_summary: The study found that pet therapy significantly improved sleep and life quality in the intervention group compared to the control group, with no significant changes observed in the control group. A statistically significant difference was noted between the two groups.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals living in a nursing home in Tokat province, Turkey.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 6 weeks (12 sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation and impact of robotic pet therapy on managing pain, agitation, delirium, immobility, and sleep disruption (PADIS) in ICU patients.
results_summary: The study found that robotic pet therapy can be successfully implemented in the ICU and may serve as a simple, safe, and beneficial nonpharmacologic intervention for PADIS. However, specific quantitative outcomes or statistical significance were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: ICU patients in the North Florida/South Georgia Veterans Health System.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pet therapy on stress and social anxiety levels in physically disabled children.
results_summary: The study found that pet therapy significantly reduced perceived stress and social anxiety scores in the intervention group compared to the control group (p<0.05).
population_specificity: Physically disabled children attending Special Education and Rehabilitation Centers.
study_duration: November 2019 to September 2020 (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pet therapy in improving social, communicative, and psychological outcomes in adults over 65 with neurocognitive disorders.
results_summary: The study found some positive effects of pet therapy, such as increased social competencies and reduced anxiety, but methodological limitations (e.g., small sample sizes, lack of rigor) prevented generalizable conclusions.
population_specificity: Adults over 65 years old with neurocognitive disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of animal-assisted interventions (AAIs) on patient, family, and healthcare provider experience in emergency and ambulatory care settings.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with some before-after studies suggesting benefits in reducing anxiety/distress, but RCTs generally showed no significant effects on patient-reported anxiety/distress, observed anxiety/distress, or pain. Effects on HCP stress were positive but nonsignificant.
population_specificity: Patients, families, and healthcare providers in emergency and ambulatory care settings (total n=341 patients, 146 HCPs, 122 child caregivers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) PET imaging in assessing therapy response for metastatic prostate cancer, addressing limitations of conventional methods.
results_summary: PSMA PET imaging shows promise in improving therapy response assessment for metastatic prostate cancer, correlating well with PSA levels and clinical outcomes, though it has limitations due to variable effects of treatments on PSMA expression.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic prostate cancer

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of emotional support dogs, dog therapy, or dog ownership on neurological disorders such as stroke, dementia, Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, Huntington's disease, epilepsy, and acute brain injury.
results_summary: Dog therapy and ownership improved mood, quality of life, and disease symptoms across multiple neurological disorders and encouraged physical activity, which benefited diseases like Huntington's disease. The approach was found to be safe and effective for chronic and progressive neurological disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological disorders (stroke, dementia, Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, Huntington's disease, epilepsy, acute brain injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether pet therapy could decrease anxiety levels in patients on Behavioral Health and Pediatric inpatient units.
results_summary: The study found that therapy dog visitations significantly lowered anxiety levels in both Behavioral Health and Pediatric participants, supporting the hypothesis. The positive effect was measured using the State Anxiety Scale and a Pediatric Emoji Method.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients on Behavioral Health (BHU) and Pediatric (PEDS) inpatient units.
effective_dosage: Up to 15 minutes with a therapy dog and handler.
study_duration: Single session (posttest measured 1 hour after intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a brief pet therapy visit compared to a control intervention (puzzle completion) on reducing anxiety in hospitalized children.
results_summary: Pet therapy significantly reduced anxiety in hospitalized children more than the control intervention (p = .004), and parents reported high satisfaction with the program. Both groups showed decreased anxiety, but the pet therapy group had a greater reduction.
population_specificity: Hospitalized children aged 6–17 (N = 93).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between pet ownership and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).
results_summary: The study found that pet ownership was significantly associated with ABPA in CF patients (OR 5.0227, p = 0.029) and an increased number of exacerbations (OR 6.446, p = 0.043). Other outcomes did not significantly differ between pet owners and non-pet owners.
population_specificity: 109 patients with CF aged 1-64 years (55 pet owners, 54 non-pet owners).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of animal-assisted intervention (AAI) on psychological traits, anxiety, and pain in systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients undergoing iloprost intravenous infusion.
results_summary: AAI significantly reduced anxiety state levels, pain perception (VAS), and improved social interaction and extroversion traits compared to control groups. It also enhanced the capacity to avoid unwanted thoughts and reduced trait anxiety (STAI-T) and alexithymia (TAS) scores.
population_specificity: 42 systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients undergoing iloprost intravenous infusion.
study_duration: Duration of the intervention not explicitly stated, but involved 20 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of Pet Therapy (PT) in reducing physiological stress levels (blood pressure and heart rate) and subjective stress and anxiety scores, while also investigating potential moderators like sample characteristics and PT modifications.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant reductions in heart rate, self-reported anxiety, and self-reported stress after PT exposure, but no significant differences in blood pressure. Sample characteristics and PT modifications significantly moderated PT's effect on stress responses.
population_specificity: 1,310 participants across 28 articles, including various age groups and health statuses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to prioritize and assess the risk of transmissible diseases in companion animals, focusing on zoonotic potential and agricultural economic impact.
results_summary: The study identified 15 high-priority diseases, analyzed their transmission risks, and highlighted knowledge gaps in risk assessments for companion animals. It found inconsistent case definitions and insufficient data for meta-analyses.
population_specificity: Domesticated pets (dogs, cats), captive wild animals, and production animal species.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effectiveness of pet therapy in improving well-being among elderly individuals living in a nursing home.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in anxiety, depression, apathy, loneliness, and improved quality of life, with the greatest improvement observed in quality of life. The experimental group showed better outcomes compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals residing in a nursing home.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of pet therapy and art-making on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and anxiety reduction in patients diagnosed with malignant glioma.
results_summary: Preliminary findings suggest that pet therapy and reflective art-making significantly improved patients' overall wellbeing and reduced anxiety about future uncertainty. The interventions provided meaningful positive changes in HRQoL despite the lack of survival benefits from traditional treatments.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with malignant glioma (malignant primary brain tumors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pet therapy could reduce blood pressure and heart rate in older adults compared to volunteer-only visits, and to explore relationships among stress, pet attitude, social support, and health status.
results_summary: The study found that pet therapy significantly decreased blood pressure and heart rate in older adults, supporting its therapeutic benefits. The findings suggest community health nurses should consider implementing pet therapy programs.
population_specificity: 28 community-dwelling older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to present the implementation of a pet therapy program with infection prevention guidelines and assess its safety and feasibility over a 16-year period.
results_summary: The study found that the pet therapy program, with strict infection prevention measures, resulted in no documented cases of transmitted infections over 16 years, averaging 20,000 interactions annually. The program demonstrated both safety and scalability in a healthcare setting.
population_specificity: Patients in a healthcare delivery setting (specific population not further detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how Pet Therapy, applied through Relational-Cultural Theory, fosters symbiotic relationships between pets and prison inmates, potentially improving inmates' interpersonal relationships.
results_summary: The study found that Pet Therapy in correctional institutions promotes growth-fostering relationships and reciprocal empathy, reducing isolation and aiding in healing. The symbiotic bond between pets and inmates also enhances their relationships with other people.
population_specificity: Prison inmates in correctional institutions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of animal-facilitated therapy (AFT) on quality of life in hospitalized pediatric oncology patients.
results_summary: AFT demonstrated physiological and psychological benefits, including reduced pain, improved vital signs, decreased fear, increased socialization, and reduced emotional distress in pediatric inpatients. It also improved mood, symptom management, and overall quality of life for high-risk patients.
population_specificity: Hospitalized pediatric oncology patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and summarize the effectiveness, findings, and limitations of pet therapy as an alternative treatment for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Studies showed positive effects of pet therapy, including high satisfaction rates among participants' families, but major limitations included lack of control groups and small sample sizes. Future research should incorporate better study designs and larger samples to validate pet therapy for ASD.
population_specificity: Primarily children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pet therapy could reduce test anxiety and improve performance among nursing students.
results_summary: Anecdotal evidence from the study suggests that pet therapy with a Golden Retriever reduced test anxiety and improved nursing student performance. The abstract does not provide statistical or clinical data to substantiate these claims.
population_specificity: Nursing students at one school.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of pet therapy on symptoms of anxiety and depression in antepartum hospitalized women with high-risk pregnancies.
results_summary: Pet therapy significantly reduced depressive symptoms (mean score improved from 10.1 to 6.3) and state anxiety (mean score improved from 44.8 to 34.5), with both results statistically significant (P<0.0001 and P<0.001, respectively).
population_specificity: Antepartum hospitalized women with high-risk pregnancies.

study_goal: To determine whether pet therapy interventions improve physiological, behavioral, and mood outcomes in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: Patients showed significant decreases in pain, respiratory rate, and negative mood state, along with increased perceived energy level. Both quantitative and qualitative findings supported reduced tension/anxiety and fatigue, as well as improved overall mood.
population_specificity: 59 hospitalized patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pet therapy on cognitive function, mood, and perceived quality of life in elderly inpatients with dementia, depression, and psychosis.
results_summary: The pet therapy group showed a 50% reduction in depressive symptoms (GDS) and a modest improvement in cognitive function (MMSE), with most participants reporting enhanced quality of life. The control group also improved, but the pet therapy group demonstrated a more significant positive effect on depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: Elderly inpatients (mean age 84.7 years; 95.2% women) with dementia, depression, and psychosis in long-term care facilities.
